awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Showups vs. Lineups: A Comparison of Two Identification Techniques
awd_abstract_narration:
In the area of eyewitness identification, few studies compare showups (one-person identifications), simultaneous lineups (all lineup members viewed simultaneously), and sequential lineups (lineup members viewed one at a time) to determine which is most accurate. The current research involves a series of experiments in which participants will first watch a staged video of multiple perpetrators breaking into a storage unit and then complete a showup, sequential lineup, and simultaneous lineup, each involving a different suspect. Finally, participants will indicate their confidence in their decision and complete additional questions about the manipulation and witnessing experience. The current research has three objectives: to compare identification accuracy between showups and lineups within a single set of studies; to develop techniques that improve eyewitness identification; and to promote a better understanding of the underlying memory and decision-making processes that occur in showup and lineup identifications using formal computational models. 

The research focuses on improving eyewitness identification in showups and reducing the fallibility of eyewitness evidence leading to the wrongful conviction of the innocent.

The U.S. Supreme Court, state courts, and social science researchers have stated that showup identifications (one-person identifications) are less reliable than lineup identifications. Moreover, 74% of eyewitness experts endorsed false identifications as more likely to occur from showups than lineups. Although showups appeared to be less reliable, existing research provided mixed support of this view (Goodsell, Wetmore, Neuschatz, & Gronlund, 2013). Therefore, we set out to compare identification accuracy between showups and lineups within a single set of studies to determine if showups really were less accurate.

            In our first study, Gronlund et al., 2012, we utilized data from Gronlund et al. (2009) that compared simultaneous (all members shown at once) and sequential (members shown one at a time) lineup formats, and added a comparable showup condition. Results showed that lineups were always superior to the showup, except when the suspect was placed early in the sequential lineup (position 2). After demonstrating that showups were inferior, we next set out to investigate two possible situations where the use of showups differed from lineups: (1) the presence of clothing and (2) retention interval and lineup fairness.

            First, because showups can be conducted relatively quickly after a crime occurs, it may be the case that the witness can use clothing as a cue to aid their decision making. Prior research had suggested that clothing match would only raise the risk to an innocent suspect, however our examination (Wetmore et al., 2015a) found that witnesses were better able to differentiate between guilty and innocent suspects when there was a clothing match from crime to showup identification.

            Secondly, showups conducted quickly may have an advantage over lineups because lineups are typically conducted long after the crime occurs. However, showups could still be at a disadvantage because showups contain no fillers (known innocent lineup members) to protect against a witness who is too willing to make a choice. In Wetmore et al. (2015b), we conducted a study comparing showups to lineups containing either good fillers (matching the description of the perpetrator) or poor fillers, where witnesses were being testing immediately (five minutes after viewing a mock crime) or two days later. Results showed that lineups were always better – even when comparing showups conducted immediately to lineups conducted two days later.

            Finally, we conducted an examination of the extant literature plus the studies we conducted, resulting in over 7500 participants, which confirmed that showups are an inferior procedure to lineups. The data also reveal that confidence is better calibrated to accuracy for lineups than for showups. That is, witnesses expressing higher confidence tended to be more accurate when making decisions from lineups.

The data also reveal that confidence is better calibrated to accuracy for lineups than for showups. That is, witnesses expressing higher confidence tended to be more accurate when making decisions from lineups.

            Lastly, we utilized a computational memory model (WITNESS, Clark, 2003) designed for eyewitness identification to explore these findings. As originally conceived, the model incorrectly predicts similar levels of performance across lineups and showups. However, our data show that simultaneous lineups are superior to sequential lineups and showups, and that placing the suspect later (e.g., position 5 or 6) in the sequential lineup can sometimes result in improved performance. Therefore, we implemented an alternative idea that assumes that participants learn to distinguish which features are useful as the sequential lineup unfolds, but are unable to do this in a showup. This idea resulted in a closer correspondence of the model predictions to the observed data, but still predicted showup performance to be better than the observed data. This suggests that poor showup performance arises from an additional factor that suppresses performance.
